metadata.title: Hydroisomerization catalysts with enhanced metal charge density prepared by a novel low temperature loading method

Bifunctional catalysts, consisting of metal and acid sites, can be applied in the alkane hydroisomerization reaction, and the process of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation at the metal sites can balance the isomerization and cracking routes, carbocation rearrangement at acidic sites affecting the hydroisomerization performance. Metals are traditionally prepared at high temperature which results in metal agglomeration. To address this drawback, a low-temperature method for catalyst loading is proposed. The method provides catalysts with smaller particle sizes and higher dispersion to prevent metal agglomeration. Specifically, when the loading capacity of metal Pt is 0.3 wt%, this method results in both single atoms and metal clusters within the catalyst. And the catalyst shows a balanced metal-acid function once capacity for Pt loading increased to 0.5 wt%. Moreover, the electron density of Pt following metal loading on g-C3N4 support increased, and the turnover frequency (TOF) of each metal site also increased with the rise of nPt/nA. Furthermore, it is noted that the catalyst prepared by low-temperature loading shows significant increased hydroisomerization activity and selectivity compared to those prepared with the traditional method, with an isomer yield of up to 68.2 %. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydroisomerization reaction Bifunctional catalyst Low temperature loading method Single atom Metal cluster Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction As the demand for energy increases, the recent focus has shifted towards overcoming technical challenges such as high energy consumption and emissions associated with the use of fossil fuels. Achieving efficient and clean utilization of fossil energy has become the core of sustainable energy usage strategy. Coal is an abundant fossil fuel resource with significant reserves in certain regions, making it an economically viable source of energy extraction with the right technology used [1]. Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) synthesis is an indirect liquefaction procedure that transforms coal into liquid fuel for more efficient and wider utilization of coal energy resources [2]. The F-T synthesis generates wax, which can be converted into a lubrication oil through a hydroisomerization reaction. This conversion alters the structure of the wax from linear to branched chain. The transformation not only reduces pour point and improves low-temperature fluidity of the lubricating oil, but it also facilitates the conversion of a part of the diesel distillate into high-value liquid products. Fischer-tropsch wax is mainly composed of high-carbon alkanes. The hydroisomerization reaction of long-chain alkane is facilitated by bifunctional catalyst containing metal sites and acid sites, hydrocarbons can be hydrogenated or dehydrogenated at metal sites, and hydrocarbons can have their carbon-carbon bonds combined or broken at acid sites. Specifically, the (de)hydrogenation is provided by platinum, palladium, nickel or their combination [3–6]. Acid sites, such as SAPO-11, SAPO-31, ZSM-22, ZSM-23, ZSM-48 and Beta zeolites have been widely used for acidic functions [7–11]. The isomerization selectivity of bifunctional catalysts relies on the ratio of metal sites to acid sites, specifically the quantity and intensity of Bronsted acid sites, as well as the quantity and dispersion of metals [12–14]. The (de)hydrogenation characteristic of metals is significantly influenced by their particle size. When metal particles shrink to the nanoscale or even single-atomic clusters, their surface area-to-volume ratio increases significantly. This high surface area allows more active sites to be exposed to the reactant. Besides, nanoclusters and single atoms also exhibit unique electronic and geometric properties due to quantum effects, which can lead to changes in catalytic performance. For example, smaller metal nanoparticles can exhibit higher catalytic activity in reactions such as hydrogenation [15], oxidation [16], and reduction [17] due to the increased number of exposed active sites and the possibility of adjusting the electronic structure. In addition, the unique geometric arrangement of atoms inside the nanoclusters can create specific binding sites that effectively catalyze certain reactions [18,19]. Apart from the particle size, increasing the electron density of a metal also have a significant impact on its catalytic behavior [20]. Higher electron density typically leads to stronger metal-reactant interactions and a higher propensity for electron transfer. This can enhance the activation of reactant molecules and lower the energy barriers for catalytic reactions. For example, in some cases for reactions involving redox processes, metals with higher electron density might show improved performance, such as oxygen reduction in fuel cells or carbon dioxide reduction. These metals can facilitate electron transfer more effectively and stabilize reaction intermediates, leading to better overall catalytic efficiency. However, the metal particle size will increase and the surface volume ratio will decrease under high temperatures. This is owing to the high surface energy of metal nanoparticles, which will reduce the availability of the catalytic active site, and the overall activity of the catalyst will be reduced or even inactivated. There are two mechanisms of metal sintering: firstly, the migration path of metal atoms on the carrier and sintering into larger particles; Secondly, the Ostwald maturation path of metal atoms moving from small particles to large particles one by one [21,22]. At present, researchers mainly develop sinter-resistant catalysts through four strategies: firstly, strong metal-support interaction [23]; Secondly, coating with oxide or carbon [22]; Thirdly, coating with mesoporous material [24]; Fourthly, fixation of molecular sieve crystal [25]. However, at present, the above strategies basically require high-temperature sintering steps, which not only consumes energy, but also has the risk of agglomeration of nanoparticles. This study proposes a new type of bifunctional catalyst prepared by an improved low temperature loading method. Metal Pt was firstly loaded on g-C3N4 at low temperature and combined with molecular sieve SAPO-11 to prepare a bifunctional catalyst, to avoid metal aggregation at high temperatures. Then, physicochemical properties, catalytic activity and selectivity of the catalyst were investigated. These results show that the low temperature loading method of the catalyst can be applied to hydroisomerization reaction of alkanes, which helps to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity. Experimental section Materials SAPO-11 molecular sieve, with a molar composition of 1.0Al2O3:0.63SiO2:0.82P2O5, was acquired from Jiangsu XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6⋅6H2O, 99.9 %, Pt ≥ 37.5 wt%), n-dodecane (C12H26, 99 %), urea and anhydrous alcohol (C2H5OH, ≥99.7 %) were bought from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd.. Synthesis of bifunctional catalysts Low temperature loading method In the low-temperature loading method, firstly, urea was calcined at 480 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 in a muffle furnace under air atmosphere to obtain graphitized carbon nitride (g- C3N4). Next, 0.3 g of g-C3N4 was dispersed in 100 ml of deionized water and later 2.4 mL of H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (0.049 mol L−1) was added in. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 8 h, centrifuged, and dried overnight in an oven. After drying, the powder was heated in a tube furnace at 125 °C for 2 h in nitrogen atmosphere. The obtained powder was mixed with 2.7 g of SAPO-11 molecular sieve and ground by agate mortar to obtain Pt/C3N4-SAPO-11 bifunctional catalyst. The synthesized catalyst was named as 0.3Pt/CN-S11(L). Add 4 mL of H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (0.049 mol L−1) to obtain 0.5Pt/CN-S11(L) with mass percentage of Pt at 0.5 wt% and 5.6 mL of H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (0.049 mol L−1) for 0.7Pt/CN-S11(L) with mass percentage of Pt at 0.7 wt% Conventional impregnation method The conventional method also began by calcinating urea at 480 °C for 4 h inside a muffle furnace in air atmosphere to obtain g- C3N4. Then 2.4 mL of H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (0.049 mol L−1) was dropwise added to 0.3 g of g-C3N4, and the mixture was evenly stirred and was left at room temperature overnight. The sample was then ground into fine powders and dried for 4 h at 80 °C. Then calcined it for 3 h at 370 °C in air atmosphere. A heating rate of 1 °C min−1 was used for the calcination process. After cooling to room temperature, the powder was mixed with 2.7 g of SAPO-11 molecular sieve, and were ground together to produce 0.3Pt/CN-S11(N) catalyst. Catalysts characterizations A D8 Advance diffractometer from Bruker, Germany, was used for X-ray diffraction (XRD) investigation on the produced catalysts using Cu Kα (1.514 Å) radiation, with a scanning speed of 5 ° min−1 and accelerating voltage of 40 kV and 40 mA. A 5110 ICP-OES spectrometer from Agilent, China, was used to measure Pt content of catalysts. Specific surface area and pore size distribution of catalysts, which had been vacuum degassed for 10 h at 300 °C, were characterized via N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms using an Autosorb-iQ gas adsorption analyzer, USA. Morphological properties were captured using a JSM-7401F scanning electron microscope from Joel, Japan, with an acceleration voltage of 1 kV. Structural characteristics of Pt were investigated via high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) using n FEI Talos F200S electron microscope at 120 kV. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was used to acquire transmission electron microscope (TEM) images from its metal distribution. The CO pulse chemisorption and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were investigated using an AutoChem 2920 temperature-programmed chemical adsorption instrument from Micromeritics, USA. Adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) FT-IR spectra were acquired using the specimens in an in-situ cell on self-supporting wafers.; a Nicolet 380 instrument from American thermal power company was used to analyze the data and distinguish between different acid types. After activating th e wafer sample (100 mg) leave for one hour at 400 °C under a vacuum of 10−2 Pa, a pure vapor of pyridine was adsorbed for thirty minutes at 30 °C. Acidity of the produced catalysts was characterized by identifying their different acid sites by evacuating the adsorbed pyridine for 60 min at 250 °C and 350 °C respectively. All Py-IR spectra were obtained by adjusting the wafer's weight. The elemental composition of catalysts was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on an ESCALAB 25xi, USA with a 1 × 10−8 vacuum degree and an Al Kα anode target, both before and after Pt loading on g-C3N4. Catalytic evaluation Using a stainless tube, n-dodecane (n-C12) was hydroisomerized in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. Prior to testing, the catalyst particles must be loaded into the reactor tube's isothermal zone after being compressed, crushed, and sieved through a 20–40 mesh screen and diluted with quartz sand (20–40 mesh). A reduction reaction is conducted in hydrogen at 400 °C for 4 h, while maintaining an atmospheric pressure and a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 and an H2 flow rate of 80 mL min−1. The evaluation was carried out following reduction: Reaction temperature control was set between 320 °C and 400 °C, reaction pressure was set at 2 bar, and the H2/n-C12 M ratio was set at 15. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was set at 1.5 h−1. A gas chromatograph fitted with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-1HT capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.1 μm) was utilized to identify the liquid products. The obtained product's component distributions were examined using a mass spectrometer for gas chromatography. The following formula can be used to determine isomer yield, isomer selectivity, and n-C12 conversion: c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = n − C 12 c o n s u m p t i o n n − C 12 f e e d × 100 % s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = i s o − C 12 f o r m e d n − C 12 c o n s u m p t i o n × 100 % y i e l d ( % ) = i s o − C 12 f o r m e d n − C 12 f e e d × 100 The turnover frequency (TOF) for each metal site designated as TOFn-C12 and TOFi-C12 were determined using the subsequent formula: T O F n − C 12 = R a t e o f c o n v e r t e d n − dodecane ( m o l g c a t − 1 h − 1 ) N u m b e r o f m e t a l s i t e s ( m o l g c a t − 1 ) T O F i − C 12 = R a t e o f y i e l d e d i s o − dodecane ( m o l g c a t − 1 h − 1 ) N u m b e r o f m e t a l s i t e s ( m o l g c a t − 1 ) Results and discussion Physicochemical properties Structure and chemical composition of the synthesized catalysts and the pure SAPO-11 are presented in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 8.1 o, 9.8 o and 21.9 o–23.5 o belong to a typical SAPO-11 phase with AEL topology (PDF-47–0614) [26,27]. No significant change to the diffraction peak intensity is observed from the synthesized catalysts, which indicates their crystal structures do not change after the Pt loading and composite mixing. In addition, no Pt-related diffraction peak was detected in the XRD patterns and this can be attributed to the comparatively low loading of Pt (0.3 wt%−0.7 wt%) and its small particle size. Fig. 2 a shows N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts. A sudden and steep increase in adsorption curves at relative pressure P/P0 between 0.0 and 0.1 indicates the presence of micropores in their structure (type I isotherm). Whilst the type H4 hysteresis loop observed along P/P0 between 0.4 and 1.0 indicates the presence of mesoporous structure (type IV isotherm). Comparing to the isotherm curves obtained from pure SAPO-11 and g-C3N4, as presented in Figure S3 (Supporting Information), it can be concluded that all synthesized catalysts contain a mixture of type I and type IV pore structures. Distribution of pore sizes in the synthesized catalysts obtained from gas adsorption analyzer are presented in Fig. 2b. Due to the large pore structure of g-C3N4, low temperature loading method shows a higher dispersion of Pt on the catalyst, and the highest dispersion is shown when the loading amount of Pt is 0.5 wt% as shown in Table 1 . Fig. 3 shows SEM images of catalysts produced using the conventional and low temperature loading methods with different loadings of Pt content. Comparing to a pure SAPO-11 sample, as shown in Figure S1, it is evident that the addition of Pt particles resulted in no significant change in the catalysts’ morphology. Table 1 lists out specific surface area and total pore size volume of pure SAPO-11 and the synthesized catalysts. The size of Pt particles increased when loading at high temperature which leads to the blocked pores and channels of g-C3N4, so 0.3Pt/CN-S11(N) catalyst has the lowest micropore volume. Similarly, 0.5Pt/CN-S11(L) has the highest micropore volume with the lowest size of Pt particles. Structural information of the synthesized catalysts at atomic scale was investigated using a HAADF-STEM analysis and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4a and 4b display that Pt particles are evenly and well dispersed on g-C3N4 after low temperature loading process. Fig. 4c reveals that the presence of single atoms and metal clusters when the loading content of Pt is 0.3 wt%. In addition, the metal particle size of catalysts with different synthesis processes was compared. Under the same loading of Pt, the metal particle size of the catalyst obtained by conventional impregnation method was 3.63 nm, which was much larger than that obtained by low temperature loading method. Table 1 lists the dispersion (DPt) and statistical mean size (dPt) of Pt as measured by CO adsorption. By using the conventional impregnation procedure, the catalyst's metal dispersion is 35.5 %, while the catalyst prepared by the low-temperature impregnation method can reach 41.6 % under the same metal loading condition, and the maximum can reach 50.9 % when the metal loading increase to 0.5 wt%. Moreover, the metal particle size obtained by the low-temperature loading method is smaller, which is basically consistent with the observed value in TEM images. However, there are inevitable deviations between the two calculation methods. Acidity In order to evaluate the surface acidity of the synthetic bifunctional catalyst, the number of Lewis (L) and Brønsted (B) acid sites was calculated by the area integral of the bands at 1445−1 and 1545 cm−1 in the pyridine absorption infrared spectrum (Py-IR) detected at 250 °C and 350 °C to calculate the number of weak/medium and strong acid sites, as shown in Fig. 5 a and 5b. The weakly adsorbed pyridine molecules' desorption causes the peak area to drastically decrease as the exhaust temperature rises from 250 °C to 350 °C, the medium/strong acid site's acidity is represented by the peak area that remains. In addition, the type and strength of the acid can be distinguished by the adsorption of pyridine molecules into the acid site in AEL zeolite micropores. The peaks at 1445–1450 cm−1 and 1540–1550 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine molecules chemically adsorbed on L acid and B acid sites [14,28], respectively, while the peak at 1490 cm−1 is the result of the interaction of the two sites. Table 2 provides a summary of the Py-IR characterization quantitative calculation results. Apparently, catalysts synthesized by low temperature method have a lower Brønsted acidity than those obtained by conventional impregnation method. Meanwhile, the molar ratio of Brønsted acid sites to total acid sites decreases with the increase of Pt loading amount. Because the particle size of the metal increases with the increase of the metal loading as shown in Fig. 4, larger metals will block the pores and reduce the acidity of the catalyst. Besides, the content of C3N4 of 0.3Pt/CN-S11(N) comparison catalyst decreased during loading process led to the increased proportion of SAPO-11, so it has highest Bronsted acid density. Stronger acidity induces hydroisomerization reaction towards cracking with lower selectivity of catalysts. Therefore, the acidity and balance between metal-acid capacity is essential for bifunctional catalysts. It is also noted that the catalyst prepared by conventional impregnation method had the lowest value of nPt/nA, which is the ratio of total number of exposed Pt sites to the total number of Brønsted acid sites. Catalyst prepared by the low temperature impregnation method had higher nPt/nA value, but decreased from 0.237 to 0.039 with increasing Pt loadings, which was consistent with the following catalytic performance. The nPt/nA ratio has a suitable performance range to determine the metal-acid balance in bifunctional catalysts. The nPt/nA ratio (0.1) of sample 0.5Pt/CN-S11 confirms to the range of ideal bifunctional catalysts (0.1–0.15), indicating that metal-acid function is balanced, which is conducive to the progress of hydroisomerization as mentioned above [6]. Metallic properties Surface chemistry of Pt of the prepared catalysts was characterized using H2-TPR technique under varying thermal conditions, and their spectra are shown in Fig. 5c. Peaks observed on the spectra are typically related to the contained metals of various states [29]. Two hydrogen consumption peaks are found on the H2-TPR spectra of the comparison catalyst 0.3Pt/CN-S11(N) [30], the first strong peak around 425 ℃ results from platinum interacting with molecular sieve, and the second peak may be the interaction between platinum and carrier at high temperature [31]. The peak area of the catalyst prepared by the low temperature loading method is higher than that prepared by the conventional impregnation method, indicating that more metals are exposed on the surface of the catalyst, which agrees with the CO adsorption data, and also means better reducibility. Moreover, as the Pt content increases, more metals are squeezed into some easily reducible exposed locations, based on the shift of reduction temperature to lower temperature for the catalysts prepared by low temperature loading method. Fig. 5d exhibits N 1 s XPS spectra. Li proposed that during the low temperature loading process, the Pt atoms were distributed on top of the g-C3N4 network's five-membered rings to form the Pt-N bond, thus enabling the enhanced dispersion of Pt [32]. The peak migrated to a higher energy side after loading Pt single atoms, suggesting that the presence of Pt atoms reduces the electron density of N atoms. The establishment of Pt-N coordination bonds is responsible for this [34]. It can be seen that in the catalyst synthesized by low temperature method, the binding energy of N moves to a higher level which indicates the decrease of its electron density, then lower electron density of N element leads to higher electron density of Pt. The XPS Pt 4d signal is too weak with strong noise background, resulting in a poor signal peak, so the increase in the electron density of Pt element can only be proved through XPS of N indirectly. Overall, bifunctional catalysts generated in this study show good dispersion of Pt atom and high activity, by taking advantage of the N/C coordinating framework created by the distinct tri-s-triazine structure of g-C3N4 [32]. Catalytic performance Stability and catalytic performance of the produced catalysts were studied using a n-C12 hydroisomerization reaction and the results are presented in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6a shows that conversion rate of n-C12 increases with the increase of reaction temperature, and the catalytic activity of the catalyst prepared by low temperature loading method is significantly higher than that prepared by conventional loading method. The highest catalytic activity was achieved from the 0.5Pt/CN-S11(L) catalyst due to its balanced metal load and acid content. As shown in Fig. 6b, at around 10 % conversion, the obtained i-C12 selectivity is 100 %. When the conversion of n-C12 increases, the selectivity of i-C12 decreases, indicating that the occurrence of side cracking reaction. The conventional impregnation catalyst exhibits the lowest i-C12 selectivity due to its higher cracking selectivity. For catalysts prepared by low temperature loading method, the selectivity of catalysts, following the order of 0.3Pt/CN-S11(L) <0.5Pt/CN-S11(L)<0.7Pt/CN-S11(L), because the (de)hydrogenation function of catalysts is weakened due to the low metal load. Fig. 6c shows the relationship between isomer yield and n-C12 conversion, conventional impregnation catalyst exhibits lower yield due to its low catalytic activity and selectivity. The distribution of isomer product components of all catalysts at the reaction temperature of 380 °C is shown in Fig. 7 , the n-C12 conversion reaches 56.9 % for 0.3Pt/CN-S11(N), which is much lower than that prepared by low temperature loading method, for example, 92.4 % for 0.3Pt/CN-S11(L), 96.9 % for 0.5Pt/CN-S11(L) and 96 % for 0.7Pt/CN-S11(L). The liquid product components mainly comprise mono- or multi-branched isomers, in which the mono-branched isomer is dominant. It is noticed that the cracked liquid produced by the bifunctional catalysts from the low temperature loading method possessed higher ratio of mono- to multi-branched isomers. In addition, the cracked liquid volume also increases with higher Pt loadings, probably due to increase in acidity arising from more Lewis acid sites [33]. High liquid yield means fewer cracked gas products are produced, indicating a significant inhibition on catalytic isomerization due to β-scission [34]. This can be found that the catalyst prepared by the conventional method contains a considerable amount of cracked gas in the catalytic product at a low conversion rate, which led to the reduction in both isomer selectivity and cracked liquid generation. Under the same metal loading condition, the catalyst prepared by low temperature loading method has higher conversion rate and lower cracking gas. The conversion of TOF (per metal site) to n-C12 in the n-C12 hydroisomerization reaction, and the resulting i-C12 content (TOF n -C12 and TOF i -C12, respectively), are considered to be the best indicator of the catalytic performance as shown in Fig. 8 . With the increase of nPt/nA, TOF n -C12 and TOF i -C12 increased. When nPt/nA =0.017, the conversion of n-C12 and selectivity of i-C12 were 15 % and 72 % respectively. When nPt/nA was increased to 0.039, the hydroisomerization activity and selectivity of the catalyst prepared by low temperature impregnation were significantly improved (38 % and 85 %, respectively), indicating that the presence form of metal and the balance between metal and acid played an important role [48]. Due to the advantages of the low temperature loading preparation method, the metal dispersion and electron density are increased, meanwhile the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation function of catalysts are enhanced, resulting in the residence time of the carbocation intermediate in the acidic site is shortened to avoid cracking reaction. Conclusion This research presents a novel method of synthesizing a bifunctional catalyst at low temperatures, leading to enhanced activity, selectivity, and improved atomic utilization efficiency of precious metal. The method involves supporting Pt metal on g-C3N4 and combining it with SAPO-11 molecular sieve. TEM results show that Pt is dispersed uniformly on g-C3N4 and the metal particle size is much smaller compared to that prepared by conventional impregnation method. With the addition of Pt on g-C3N4, the binding energy of N moves to a higher level which indicates the decrease of its electron density, then lower electron density of N element leads to higher electron density of Pt. The catalyst obtained by low temperature loading method has higher activity and selectivity than that prepared by conventional impregnation method. The resulting product contains more isomers, which can significantly improve its low temperature fluidity, and can be used to catalyze normal chain alkanes to branched chain alkanes via a hydroisomerization reaction. The results of this study effectively demonstrate the feasibility of the low temperature loading method in atomic utilization of precious metal in designing a metal-molecular sieve bifunctional catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional catalysts, consisting of metal and acid sites, can be applied in the alkane hydroisomerization reaction, and the process of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation at the metal sites can balance the isomerization and cracking routes, carbocation rearrangement at acidic sites affecting the hydroisomerization performance. Metals are traditionally prepared at high temperature which results in metal agglomeration. To address this drawback, a low-temperature method for catalyst loading is proposed. The method provides catalysts with smaller particle sizes and higher dispersion to prevent metal agglomeration. Specifically, when the loading capacity of metal Pt is 0.3 wt%, this method results in both single atoms and metal clusters within the catalyst. And the catalyst shows a balanced metal-acid function once capacity for Pt loading increased to 0.5 wt%. Moreover, the electron density of Pt following metal loading on g-C3N4 support increased, and the turnover frequency (TOF) of each metal site also increased with the rise of nPt/nA. Furthermore, it is noted that the catalyst prepared by low-temperature loading shows significant increased hydroisomerization activity and selectivity compared to those prepared with the traditional method, with an isomer yield of up to 68.2 %.
coredata.dc:title: Hydroisomerization catalysts with enhanced metal charge density prepared by a novel low temperature loading method
